title should have been filled in via JavaScript

History

  • 2009-05-06 - Patrick Mueller - version 0.6
  • 2009-04-22 - Patrick Mueller - version 0.5

Table of Contents

Introduction

The nitro_pie project implements a Python module named nitro_pie which is a Python version of the C API for JavaScriptCore. JavaScriptCore is the JavaScript engine shipped with WebKit. You may want to get familiar with the JavaScriptCore framework before using this module in anger. In lieu of that, examine the test cases and the "main" runner in the module itself.

Note that the nitro_pie module does not currently expose all of the JavaScriptCore APIs. It does expose enough to do some interesting things.

Installation

The nitro_pie module is implemented in a single file, nitro_pie.py. You can just copy this file into an appropriate directory to use with other Python code.

The module makes extensive use of the ctypes module, which is included in Python distributions starting with version 2.5. The nitro_pie module has currently only be tested and used on Mac OS X 10.5, and will likely need some changes to run on other operating systems. You will also likely need to find or build a copy of JavaScriptCore for those operating systems.

Usage

There are test cases available in the test subdirectory, to see real life usage.

All usages of nitro_pie start with obtaining a JSGlobalContextRef object, via the following invocation: 

context = JSGlobalContextRef.create()

Once a context has been obtained, you can execute a script using JSContextRef's eval() method: 

result = context.eval(script)

The eval() method will return the result of evaluating JavaScript code, returning a JSValueRef instance that you can further noodle on.

To add a new function to a context that a script executes in, use the JSContextRef makeFunction() method, and then add it to the 'global' object of the context: 

context = JSGlobalContextRef.create()
    
globalObject = context.getGlobalObject()
function = context.makeFunction("print", callbackPrint)
globalObject.setProperty(context, "print", function)

The third argument to the makeFunction() method is a Python callable, which should have the following signature: 

def callback_print(context, function, thisObject, args)

The context parameter (JSContextRef) is the context that the function was invoked within. The function parameter (JSObjectRef) is the JavaScript function that is currently executing. The thisObject parameter (JSObjectRef) is the 'this' value for the invocation. The args parameter (list of JSValueRef) is the array of parameters passed to the function.

The function should return whatever value it needs to return as a JSValueRef. Here's an example of a function which prints it's arguments: 

def callbackPrint(context, function, thisObject, args):
    line = ""
    
    for valueRef in args:
        string = valueRef.toString(context)
        line   = line + string
        
    print line
    
    return context.makeUndefined()

There is currently no direct way of creating JavaScript objects or arrays other than 'primitive' values. To do this indirectly, use JSContextRef.eval(). For instance, to create a new empty object, use: 

object = context.eval("({})")

To create an array, use: 

object = context.eval("[]")

Shell Usage

nitro_pie can also be used as a command-line shell. Invoke the module as a python program, using the -h option for more help on the command line invocation.

Scripts executed in the shell have access to the following global properties, specifically added for the shell:

  • arguments - the arguments to the script. A "script name" is available as the first element of the list (similar to traditional argv handling).

  • environment - an object that contains the environment variables available to the process. Each environment variable is a property of the environment property.

  • print() - a function that prints the string representation of it's arguments, concatenated together.

  • python_exec() - a function which will run arbitrary python code. Useful to dynamically load new JavaScript functions implemented in Python. See the test_shell.py test for an example usage. The argument to this function is the name of the file to pass to Python's exec() function. The globals for the invocation are set to the current globals in effect when the python_exec code is executed. The locals for the invocation are a dictionary with a single key of context set to the JSContextRef the code is executed with.

Module Reference

In general, the functions and methods in classes in this module are veneers over the C APIs for JavaScriptCore as documented at the JavaScriptCore Framework Reference available at the ADC.

Some functions/methods take one of str | unicode | JSStringRef as a parameter. In these cases, if you pass a str or unicode value in, a JSStringRef will be temporarily created and then destroyed during the call.

Classes

JSLibraryManages the native JavaScriptCore library.
JSContextRefModels the JSContextRef type.
JSGlobalContextRefModels the JSGlobalContextRef type.
JSStringRefModels the JSStringRef type.
JSValueRefModels the JSValueRef type.
JSObjectRefModels the JSObjectRef type.
JSExceptionContains a JavaScript execution.

Class JSLibrary

Manages the native JavaScriptCore library.

You can set the libraryPath and libraryName class variables AFTER importing the module and BEFORE invoking any other code in the module. If the libraryPath variable is set, it overrides the libraryName variable.

libraryName holds the short name of the native JavaScriptCore library.

If this variable is set, but the libraryPath variable is not set, the library will be searched for in the system via a system defined method.

The default value for libraryName is "JavaScriptCore".

libraryPath holds the fully qualified name of the JavaScriptCore library.

If this variable is set, it overrides the libraryName variable setting and is used as the complete name of the library.

Static Methods

getLibrary()

Return the JavaScriptCore library as a CDLL or equivalent.

Returns:

  • ctypes.CDLL - the JavaScriptCore library in use

Raises:

  • Exception - when the library cannot be loaded

Class JSContextRef

Models the JSContextRef type.

These methods call functions defined in JSContextRef.h.

Instances of this class are not created directly; instead use the create() method of JSGlobalContextRef class.

Methods

checkScriptSyntax(script, sourceURL = None, startingLineNumber = 1)

Check the syntax of a string of JavaScript code.

Returns:

  • boolean - whether the script is syntactically correct

Parameters:

  • script (str | unicode | JSStringRef)
    the script to check

  • sourceURL (str | unicode | JSStringRef)
    the name of the script

  • startingLineNumber (int)
    the line of the source the script starts on

Raises:

  • JSException - raised when a JavaScript exception occurs during the processing of the script

eval(script, thisObject = None, sourceURL = None, startingLineNumber = 1)

Evaluate a string of JavaScript code.

Returns:

  • JSValueRef - the value of executing the script.

Parameters:

  • script (str | unicode | JSStringRef)
    the script to execute

  • thisObject (JSObjectRef)
    the object to act as this when the script executes

  • sourceURL (str | unicode | JSStringRef)
    the name of the script

  • startingLineNumber (int)
    the line of the source the script starts on

Raises:

  • JSException - raised when a JavaScript exception occurs during the processing of the script

garbageCollect()

Runs the garbage collector.

The garbage collector does need to be run explicitly, but can be by invoking this method.

getGlobalObject()

Returns the global object associated with a context.

Returns:

  • JSValueRef - the global object associated with the context

makeBoolean(value)

Creates a new JavaScript boolean value.

Returns:

  • JSValueRef - the value created

Parameters:

  • value (boolean)
    the boolean value to create

makeFunction(name, function)

Creates a JavaScript function implemented in Python.

The third argument to the makeFunction() method is a Python callable, which should have the following signature: 

def callback_print(context, function, thisObject, args)

The context parameter (JSContextRef) is the context that the function was invoked within. The function parameter (JSObjectRef) is the JavaScript function that is currently executing. The thisObject parameter (JSObjectRef) is the 'this' value for the invocation. The args parameter (list of JSValueRef) is the array of parameters passed to the function.

The function should return whatever value it needs to return as a JSValueRef. Here's an example of a function which prints it's arguments: 

def callbackPrint(context, function, thisObject, args):
    line = ""

    for valueRef in args:
        string = valueRef.toString(context)
        line   = line + string

    print line

    return context.makeUndefined()

Returns:

  • JSObjectRef - the JavaScript function just created

Parameters:

  • name (str | unicode | JSStringRef)
    the name of the function

  • function (callable)
    the Python function that implements the JavaScript function

makeNull()

Creates a new JavaScript null value.

Returns:

  • JSValueRef - the value created

makeNumber(number)

Creates a new JavaScript number value.

Returns:

  • JSValueRef - the value created

Parameters:

  • number (int |float)
    the number value to create

makeString(string)

Creates a new JavaScript string value.

Returns:

  • JSValueRef - the value created

Parameters:

  • string (JSStringRef)
    the string value to create

makeUndefined()

Creates a new JavaScript undefined value.

Returns:

  • JSValueRef - the value created

Class JSGlobalContextRef

Models the JSGlobalContextRef type.

This class is a subclass of JSContextRef.

These methods call functions defined in JSContextRef.h.

Static Methods

create()

Create a new instance of this class.

Returns:

  • JSGlobalContextRef - the new instance

Methods

release()

Release this context

retain()

Retain this context

Class JSStringRef

Models the JSStringRef type.

These methods call functions defined in JSStringRef.h.

Static Methods

asRef(string)

Creates an instance of this class from a string.

Slightly different from create, this function may also be passed an instance of this class and it will then simply return that instance. In this case, you will have to test yourself whether or not the reference was created, so you can release() it later.

Returns:

  • JSStringRef - the JSStringRef created (or passed in)

Parameters:

  • string (str | unicode | JSStringRef)
    the object to convert to a JSStringRef

create(string)

Creates an instance of this class from a string.

The caller is responsible for freeing this string with the release() method when no longer needed.

Returns:

  • JSStringRef - the JSStringRef created

Parameters:

  • string (str | unicode)
    the object to convert to a JSStringRef

Methods

release()

Retain this instance.

retain()

Retain this instance.

toString()

Convert this object to a Python string.

Returns:

  • str - always returns a UTF-8 encoding of the string

Class JSValueRef

Models the JSValueRef type.

These methods call functions defined in JSValueRef.h. This class also defines the following constants, returned from the getType() method.

  • kJSTypeUndefined
  • kJSTypeNull
  • kJSTypeBoolean
  • kJSTypeNumber
  • kJSTypeString
  • kJSTypeObject

Methods

asJSObjectRef(context)

Attempts to cast this object as a JSObjectRef.

Many values returned from APIs in this module are typed as JSValueRef (by ctypes), but are actually JSObjectRef instances. This method will cast them to JSObjectRef so you can use those methods on the object. Primitive values and strings cannot be recast.

Parameters:

  • context (JSContextRef)

Raises:

  • TypeError - raised if the object cannot be recast.

getType(context)

Returns the type of the value.

Returns:

  • int - One of the kJSType constants defined in this class.

Parameters:

  • context (JSContextRef)

isBoolean(context)

Returns whether this value is a boolean.

Returns:

  • boolean - indicator

Parameters:

  • context (JSContextRef)

isEqual(context, other)

Returns whether this value is equal to another value.

Returns:

  • boolean - indicator

Parameters:

  • context (JSContextRef)

  • other (JSValueRef)
    the value to compare against

isInstanceOf(context, constructor)

Returns whether this value is an instance of a constructor.

Returns:

  • boolean - indicator

Parameters:

  • constructor (JSValueRef)
    the constructor to test against

  • context (JSContextRef)

isNull(context)

Returns whether this value is null.

Returns:

  • boolean - indicator

Parameters:

  • context (JSContextRef)

isNumber(context)

Returns whether this value is a number.

Returns:

  • boolean - indicator

Parameters:

  • context (JSContextRef)

isObject(context)

Returns whether this value is a non-primitive object.

Returns:

  • boolean - indicator

Parameters:

  • context (JSContextRef)

isStrictEqual(context, other)

Returns whether this value is strictly equal to another value.

Returns:

  • boolean - indicator

Parameters:

  • context (JSContextRef)

  • other (JSValueRef)
    the value to compare against

isString(context)

Returns whether this value is a string.

Returns:

  • boolean - indicator

Parameters:

  • context (JSContextRef)

isUndefined(context)

Returns whether this value is undefined.

Returns:

  • boolean - indicator

Parameters:

  • context (JSContextRef)

protect(context)

Protect this value from garbage collection.

Parameters:

  • context (JSContextRef)

toBoolean(context)

Convert this value to a boolean.

Returns:

  • boolean - the converted value

Parameters:

  • context (JSContextRef)

toNumber(context)

Convert this value to a number.

Returns:

  • float - the converted value

Parameters:

  • context (JSContextRef)

toObject(context)

Convert this value to an object.

Returns:

  • JSObject - the converted value

Parameters:

  • context (JSContextRef)

toString(context)

Convert this value to a string.

This method will temporarily create a JSStringRef instance, convert that to a Python string, and then release that JSStringRef instance.

Returns:

  • str - the converted value (utf-8 encoded string)

Parameters:

  • context (JSContextRef)

toStringRef(context)

Convert this value to a JSStringRef.

Returns:

  • JSStringRef - the converted value

Parameters:

  • context (JSContextRef)

unprotect(context)

Remove the protect of this value from garbage collection.

Parameters:

  • context (JSContextRef)

Class JSObjectRef

Models the JSObjectRef type.

These methods call functions defined in JSObjectRef.h.

This class is a subclass of JSValueRef, and so all of it's methods are available to instances of this class.

This class also defines the following constants, which can be used in the setProperty() method.

  • kJSPropertyAttributeNone
  • kJSPropertyAttributeReadOnly
  • kJSPropertyAttributeDontEnum
  • kJSPropertyAttributeDontDelete

Methods

deleteProperty(context, propertyName)

Delete the property of an object.

Returns:

  • boolean - indicator of success

Parameters:

  • context (JSContextRef)

  • propertyName (str | unicode | JSStringRef)

getProperty(context, propertyName)

Return the property of an object.

Returns:

  • JSValueRef - value of the property

Parameters:

  • context (JSContextRef)

  • propertyName (str | unicode | JSStringRef)

getPropertyAtIndex(context, propertyIndex)

Return the property of an array.

Returns:

  • JSValueRef - value of the property

Parameters:

  • context (JSContextRef)

  • propertyIndex (int)

getPropertyNames(context)

Return the names of the properties of the object

Returns:

  • list of str - the names of the properties of the object

Parameters:

  • context (JSContextRef)

getPrototype(context)

Return the prototype of the object

Returns:

  • JSValueRef - the prototype of the object

Parameters:

  • context (JSContextRef)

hasProperty(context, propertyName)

Return whether the object contains the specified property.

Returns:

  • boolean - indicator

Parameters:

  • context (JSContextRef)

  • propertyName (str | unicode | JSStringRef)

isConstructor(context)

Return whether the object is a constructor.

Returns:

  • boolean - indicator

Parameters:

  • context (JSContextRef)

isFunction(context)

Return whether the object is a function.

Returns:

  • boolean - indicator

Parameters:

  • context (JSContextRef)

setProperty(context, propertyName, value, attributes = 0)

Set the property of an object.

Parameters:

  • context (JSContextRef)

  • propertyName (str | unicode | JSStringRef)

  • value (JSValueRef)

  • attributes (int)
    one of the kJSPropertyAttribute defined by this class

setPropertyAtIndex(context, propertyIndex, value)

Set the property of an array.

Parameters:

  • context (JSContextRef)

  • propertyIndex (int)

  • value (JSValueRef)

setPrototype(context, prototype)

Set the prototype of an object.

Parameters:

  • context (JSContextRef)

  • prototype (JSValueRef)

Class JSException

Contains a JavaScript execution. This exception will be raised in cases where a JavaScript runtime occurs. The value property will contain the value thrown from JavaScript, typed as a JSValueRef.

Constructor

JSException(value)

Creates a new instance of this class.

Not intended to be called directly.
